report_title: Paper Bag & Disposable Plastic Product Wholesaling in the US
executive_summary: The paper bag and disposable plastic product wholesaling industry has remained relatively protected from external forces affecting the economy. Wholesalers in this industry purchase a range of paper and plastic products from manufacturers and distribute them to retail stores, food services outlets and agricultural producers. Despite internal price-based competition and rising prices from suppliers, revenue has climbed at a CAGR of 1.2% to $135.8 billion over the past five years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Tossed the Industry the Economic Winds
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: This industry depends on stable demand from food and beverage industries, businesses and consumers. As a result, consumer spending for products from supermarkets, grocery stores and restaurants drives demand. The economic contraction caused by the COVID-19 pandemic had a huge disruptive effect across the economy, including the industry's primary downstream markets.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Rise in Consumer Spending, Especially Online Shopping, Has Boosted Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The bounce back of the economy following the pandemic-trough has created demand from across the economy for paper bags and disposable plastics, translating to greater sales for wholesalers. While new rules targeting disposable waste have undermined businesses' use of disposable products, the rise in online spending created additional demand for single-use paper and plastic as products require additional packaging.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Wholesalers Offer a Range of Products to Satisfy Different Client Markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Price competition among wholesalers has remained a constant. Price competition pressures wholesalers to charge the lowest possible price for products. Thus, while greater demand from food manufacturing ramped up demand for industry products, high internal price competition has constrained growth for wholesalers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers' sales and distribution branches have contributed to internal price competition
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Manufacturers' sales and distribution branches have contributed to internal price competition. Because these establishments are able to avoid the markups that independent wholesalers cannot, they are able to offer products at lower prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The industry wholesales to clients in the food service and healthcare industries
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry wholesales to clients in the food service and healthcare industries. Businesses in these industries rely heavily on wholesalers for supplies, which has also created pressure for wholesalers to supply an increasing range of products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CONTINUED ECONOMIC GROWTH WILL CARRY THE INDUSTRY FORWARD
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Restaurants and food service providers will continue to benefit from expected growth in disposable income and a low unemployment rate. Increased consumer traffic and purchases at single-location, full-service and chain restaurants will raise demand for paper bags and disposable plastic products. As interest rates begin to temper following a sharp rise in an effort to combat inflation, consumers will spend more heavily as disposable income continued to free up.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: PRICE COMPETITION WILL REMAIN A MAINSTAY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: High levels of price competition from warehouse clubs and supercenters will remain ever-present, especially from powerhouses like Costco. A growing number of consumers in need of paper bag and disposable plastic products are expected to turn to these supply channels instead of wholesale operators due to their ability to provide lower prices and similarly wide-ranging product lines.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: WHOLESALERS WILL CONTINUE TO SEEK TO BECOME MORE EFFICIENT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: This will primarily be driven by downstream customers looking to simplify supply chains by consolidating the number of suppliers they do business with. Merger and acquisition activity will also accelerate as distributors seek to expand product lines and capabilities. This will continue to put downward pressure on the number of active businesses in the industry. However, this will benefit the industry by allowing profit margins to widen, albeit moderately, even as price competition remains ever-present.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS MAY HINDER THE INDUSTRY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Business and consumer concerns regarding the environmental impact of plastic and paper will continue to gain importance. More states are expected to seek to limit or ban the use of plastic bags.

industry_definition: Wholesalers in this industry purchase a range of paper and plastic products from manufacturers and distribute them to retail stores, food service outlets and agricultural producers. Industry products are wide-ranging and typically include sanitary and tissue products; disposable cutlery and food trays; cartons; plastic and paper bags; paper party goods; and cardboard packaging. This industry does not include the wholesale distribution of stationery or office supplies.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - steady

key_trends: Wholesalers struggled at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic as critical downstream markets were forced to limit operations. The industry has since bounced back, although turbulence has remained.
Environmental concerns continue to put downward pressure on the industry. Consumers will increasingly seek products that can be recycled and eco-friendly.
Plastic bag bans have increased as many states have restricted or completely banned single-use plastic bags. Plastic bag bans threaten the industry.
The industry does not receive industry-specific support. There was also no industry-specific support during the height of the pandemic.
The cardboard boxes product segment surged in recent years. Increased e-commerce sales drove this segment, especially during the pandemic.
Increased industrial production has contributed to manufacturing and mining market gains. Industrial establishments require products as inputs during the production process.
The industry concentrates establishments in proximity to buyers and suppliers. Wholesalers locate in regions where major production centers are located
Wholesalers locate in regions with highly populated regions. Regions with a high concentration of retail stores and restaurants attract wholesalers.
Wholesalers compete on product price and quality primarily.
Wholesalers negotiate exclusive contracts with retailers to reduce the price of large-volume purchases.
Distributors of products that can be re-used compete with wholesalers in the industry. Substitute products include wooden crates or glass and metal containers.
The industry is fragmented. Major wholesalers do not dominate the industry because they focus on local or regional markets.
Major wholesalers have increasingly added products. Wholesalers seek to become one-stop shops to gain market share.
Purchases are the most significant expense for wholesalers. Despite volatility in critical input prices to products like plastic and resin, purchases have maintained a stable share of revenue.
Profit margins across the industry are thin. Despite volatility from the pandemic, margins have remained relatively stable.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The industry sells products in large quantities to retailers that then sell directly to consumers.
The second-largest market for operators in this industry is other wholesalers and distributors.

market_segmentation.segment: Businesses for use in their own operations
market_segmentation.segment_description: Products necessary for business operations, including plastic and paper bags not sold by retailers but used to package products sold, are categorized in this segment.

market_segmentation.segment: Manufacturing and mining industries as inputs in production
market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment consists of manufacturers and industrial mining establishments that purchase products to be used as input goods during the production process.

market_segmentation.segment: Restaurants, hotels and food service establishments
market_segmentation.segment_description: Customers in this market purchase products used in food service hospitality operations.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Industrial Paper and Plastic Products for Packaging
products_and_services.product_description: This segment comprises paper and plastic for packaging and wrapping goods and products for industrial use.
Included within the broad segment of cardboard boxes are hazardous shipping containers.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Other Paper Products, including Personal Sanitary Products
products_and_services.product_description: This segment encompasses household paper and plastic products, including paper towels and napkins. Also, this segment includes sanitary paper products, like paper diapers and feminine hygiene products.

products_and_services.product_or_service: DISPOSABLE PLASTIC BOXES, CONTAINERS, CUPS AND DISHES
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes disposable plastic boxes, containers for non-household food use, disposable plastic and paper cups, dishes and other cutlery.

products_and_services.product_or_service: INDUSTRIAL PAPER AND PLASTIC PRODUCTS FOR PACKAGING
products_and_services.product_description: This segment comprises paper and plastic for packaging and wrapping goods and products for industrial use.
This segment encompasses household paper and plastic products, including paper towels and napkins.

tier_1_suppliers: Wood Pallets & Skids Production in the US
tier_1_buyers: Packaging & Labeling Services in the US
Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment comprises paper and plastic for packaging and wrapping goods and products for industrial use.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Sanitary Paper Products, Household Paper and Plastic Products Slump During the Period
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment encompasses household paper and plastic products, including paper towels and napkins. Also, this segment includes sanitary paper products, like paper diapers and feminine hygiene products.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Cardboard Boxes Surge as E-Commerce Sales Sky-Rocket During the Pandemic Lockdown
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Included within the broad segment of cardboard boxes are hazardous shipping containers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: LAG FOLLOWING THE RECOVERY FROM THE PANDEMIC
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment includes disposable plastic boxes, containers for non-household food use, disposable plastic and paper cups, dishes and other cutlery.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: JANITORIAL EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES SLUMP AMID THE PANDEMIC
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Janitorial supplies include soap dispensers and refills, multi-purpose cleaning products and supplies, brooms and mop equipment and safety and security products.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region comprises the third-largest number of establishments in the country. New York and New Jersey contribute notably to the concentration of establishments in the region. The Mid-Atlantic contains some of the country's most highly trafficked shipping ports. New York and New Jersey have enacted plastic bag bans which have hindered wholesaler revenue in the region.

The Southeast contains the second-largest concentration of establishments. The Southeast is highly populated and wholesalers benefit from locating near downstream markets. Florida has the most establishments in the industry.

The West region comprises the most establishments in the country, accounting for slightly less than one-quarter of establishments. California is the largest state where wholesalers locate establishments. This aligns with the state's share of the population and its proximity to manufacturers. California has enacted plastic bag bans, damaging revenue in these states.

regulations_points.regulation_title: T R A D E M A R K S
regulations_points.regulation_description: Wholesaler trademark holders must comply with United States Patent and Trademark laws protecting intellectual property rights.

regulations_points.regulation_title: V A R I O U S R E G U L A T I O N S
regulations_points.regulation_description: Various other regulations regarding unfair competition impact the way a wholesaler does business.

regulations_points.regulation_title: P L A S T I C B A G B A N S
regulations_points.regulation_description: Public opposition to single-use plastic bags has increased dramatically. Eight states currently ban the use of all single-use plastic bags.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Globalization level is low but increasing.

factors_increased_barrier.factor: Industry assistance level is none and steady.
Competition level is high and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Wholesalers compete on product price and quality primarily. Wholesalers negotiate exclusive contracts with retailers to reduce the price of large-volume purchases.
Distributors of products that can be re-used compete with wholesalers in the industry. Substitute products include wooden crates or glass and metal containers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Most wholesalers operate in regionally focused markets.

A low level of market concentration characterizes the industry. Most wholesalers are small- to medium-sized and operate in local or regionally focused markets to minimize transportation costs to critical markets. This makes it difficult for any company to dominate a significant portion of the national market.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Wholesalers seek to expand market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: Wholesalers have increasingly attempted to act as a one-stop-shop for customers and have increased the type of products distributed. Wholesalers have acquired competitors to help broaden product lines.
Companies will continue to operate on a localized basis despite large wholesalers attempting to consolidate. This is expected to keep market concentration low.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs have remained stable despite the jump in the price of inputs necessary at the production level, including plastic and resin materials.
Wages constitute a small share of total revenue, as the wholesalers add little value added services and move products down the supply chain.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PROFIT MARGINS REMAIN SLIM ACROSS THE INDUSTRY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit margins have remained relatively stable throughout the period, even as revenue fluctuations and price increases of key inputs engendered volatility.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Since the labor required is not skilled, it is not difficult to secure staff for operations if necessary.
The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.
Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Products sold to restaurants or food service establishments are more susceptible to changes in consumer spending and exhibit higher volatility than products sold to households or products used by businesses that do not depend on consumer traffic.
The pandemic forced food service establishments to close or operate at reduced capacity, pressuring demand for sanitary products and contributing to a revenue slump in 2020.
This industry has various product offerings. Revenue decreases from some products are offset by increases in other products, helping to mitigate volatility in non-pandemic years.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: INDUSTRIAL PAPER AND PLASTIC PRODUCTS FOR PACKAGING SURGE ALONGSIDE E-COMMERCE SPENDING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment comprises paper and plastic for packaging and wrapping goods and products for industrial use.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Sanitary Paper Products, Household Paper and Plastic Products Slump During the Period
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment encompasses household paper and plastic products, including paper towels and napkins. Also, this segment includes sanitary paper products, like paper diapers and feminine hygiene products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Cardboard Boxes Surge as E-Commerce Sales Sky-Rocket During the Pandemic Lockdown
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Included within the broad segment of cardboard boxes are hazardous shipping containers.

FAQs.question: How have your sales been affected by the growth of online shopping?
FAQs.answer: Increasing e-commerce sales has meant an increase in demand for industry products used during the shipping process. Wholesalers may want to consider marketing packing materials and cardboard boxes more heavily to this market.

FAQs.question: How do you adjust your marketing during poor economic conditions? Do marketing costs pose a significant expense component for you company?
FAQs.answer: Demand is generally sensitive to changes in poor economic conditions, particularly consumer spending and overall consumption trends.

FAQs.question: How does your company negotiate favorable purchase costs with suppliers?
FAQs.answer: The price that wholesalers are able to secure for purchases affects their profit margins. Depending on the size and purchasing power of a wholesaler, they might have more or less negotiating power with suppliers. Wholesalers generally have low negotiating power and are price-takers.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored growth opportunities via mergers or acquisitions? On what characteristics do you compete most heavily with your primary competitors?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers have engaged in mergers and acquisitions to grow their businesses and expand their geographic footprint and product portfolios. Wholesalers selling primarily disposable plastics may want to consider buying out wholesalers who focus on other markets to avoid changing environmental regulations.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to implement technology in the purchasing process to make buying more efficient for customers?
FAQs.answer: Large companies are the most likely to have been able to implement inventory management and product tracking for its customers through online or mobile platforms. This is a new technology that, among other benefits, allows companies to better control and track inventory management, helping them to become more efficient. Companies may want to make tracking information from RFID tags available to buyers.

FAQs.question: How have you adjusted to new regulations over the past decade? How have you handled compliance costs? Have plastic bag bans in some cities resulted in a material impact on your results, positive or negative?
FAQs.answer: Recent states and cities have implemented bans or fees on the use of plastic bags, which has meant that some wholesalers have had to adjust product offerings.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor potential changes to the regulatory environment?
FAQs.answer: Monitoring such changes is essential for wholesalers because they need to decide where to invest resources and energy and adjust growth expectations.

FAQs.question: How do your profit margins compare to your main competitors? Is this something you track? Which of your product categories generate the highest margins?
FAQs.answer: Profit is generally low; however, it can differ depending on the product being sold and the value level of the brands a wholesaler carries.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected your purchase costs and selling prices over the past five years? Has this affected your financial results significantly?
FAQs.answer: For this industry, the prices of paper and plastic materials and resins have an effect on purchase costs and selling prices. It may also affect profit margins since wholesalers compete on price and cannot pass on the cost in the form of higher prices.

FAQs.question: Do you operate locally, regionally or nationally? Are your chosen locations based on proximity to key markets?
FAQs.answer: Being close to major retailers in urban areas will reduce transportation costs and enable fast and timely delivery. This is important for customer service satisfaction and cost containment.

FAQs.question: Does your company rely on the most recent technologies to optimize operations? If not, why?
FAQs.answer: Using the best available stock control, ordering, financial and decision support systems is important, as competition is high and profit margins are tight; therefore, efficiency must be maximized. However, for wholesalers seeking to minimize costs, avoiding frequent capital investments in new technology may be more in line with their strategy.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases to members?
FAQs.answer: Since margins are so competitive, the average wholesaler may not be able to increase prices to account for fluctuations in input costs.

FAQs.question: Is the rise in e-commerce hurting or helping your revenue? Do you wholesale to physical or online retailers, or both? Are you planning on (or already have) creating an online platform for customers?
FAQs.answer: Industry products are used by physical retailers, online retailers, food service establishments and more. E-commerce sales have continued to grow, which could favor wholesalers who service these clients.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in the prices of paper input products? Do you typically pass on price increases to consumers or absorb them? What steps do you take when the price of inputs are not in your favor?
FAQs.answer: When the price of paper products increases, wholesalers may decide to pass on the price to consumers. However, for industries in which price competition is intense, wholesalers may have to absorb the cost increase.

FAQs.question: How has activity in the supermarket sector affected demand for your products? How can you cater your products for this market?
FAQs.answer: Supermarkets and grocery stores require industry products not generally for sale, but to organize, display, transport and package the products they sell to consumers. Wholesalers may be able to generate more revenue in this market by offering bulk discounts, logistics services, and lower prices on plastic bag substitutes.
